articles.headline: Creators of Credit Crisis Revel in Las Vegas
articles.snippet: This year’s conference for financial professionals felt less like a celebration of risk and more like group therapy.
articles.abstract: This year’s conference for financial professionals felt less like a celebration of risk and more like group therapy.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS  It was Monday night on the Strip, and John Devaney was giving a party for himself and fellow connoisseurs of risk who have seen their hot hands go cold.

articles.headline: Is It Too Late for Yahoo?
articles.snippet: Jerry Yang faces pressure as he decides whether to try to rescue the company from Microsoft, or accept its bid to purchase Yahoo.
articles.abstract: Jerry Yang faces pressure as he decides whether to try to rescue the company from Microsoft, or accept its bid to purchase Yahoo.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  One of the first questions that Jerry Yang and his top lieutenants pondered after he became chief executive of Yahoo last summer was whether the company could remain independent. They quickly answered yes.
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Brad Stone

articles.headline: Bond Raters in Effort to Repair Credibility
articles.snippet: Standard & Poor’s and the Moody’s Corporation’s proposals to restore the credibility of their ratings have met with skepticism from some of their toughest critics.
articles.abstract: Standard & Poor’s and the Moody’s Corporation’s proposals to restore the credibility of their ratings have met with skepticism from some of their toughest critics.
articles.lead_paragraph: Under fire for their role in the mortgage crisis, Standard & Poor’s and the Moody’s Corporation are scrambling to restore confidence in their credit ratings.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Corporate Auditors Focusing on Cash and Securities
articles.snippet: Not so long ago, highly leveraged companies could get loans to bail themselves out. Now they can’t.
articles.abstract: Not so long ago, highly leveraged companies could get loans to bail themselves out. Now they can’t.
articles.lead_paragraph: What happens when cash really is trash?

articles.headline: Rescuers Script a Possible Ending for a Strike
articles.snippet: The writers’ strike is on the brink of ending in true Hollywood fashion: through connections.
articles.abstract: The writers’ strike is on the brink of ending in true Hollywood fashion: through connections.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  With Hollywood writers on the brink of ending a three-month strike, they can thank this city’s time-honored way of getting things done: connections.

articles.headline: Suit Tangles Issue of James Brown’s Estate
articles.snippet: A lawsuit filed Tuesday by two court-appointed trustees of the estate of James Brown accuses the singer’s longtime business managers of looting millions of dollars.
articles.abstract: A lawsuit filed Tuesday by two court-appointed trustees of the estate of James Brown accuses the singer’s longtime business managers of looting millions of dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: He called himself the “hardest-working man in show business,” and now, even in death, there is little peace for James Brown.

articles.headline: Romney Is Out; McCain Emerges as G.O.P. Choice
articles.snippet: Hours after Mitt Romney announced his departure to a convention of stunned conservatives, John McCain sought to make peace with the group.
articles.abstract: Hours after Mitt Romney announced his departure to a convention of stunned conservatives, John McCain sought to make peace with the group.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain all but captured the Republican presidential nomination on Thursday after Mitt Romney withdrew from the race, saying the war in Iraq and the terrorist threat made it imperative that the party unite.
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Bumiller and David D. Kirkpatrick
